consent:
Thank you for considering participating in this study. This information sheet outlines the purpose of the study and provides a description of your involvement and rights as a participant, if you agree to take part.



1. What is the research about?

We want to know what people think about different ways of getting money to small businesses. During the COVID-19 pandemic, local governments have used different approaches to deciding which businesses get help. We want to know what you think about these different programs. 



2. Do I have to take part?

No, you don't. It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. You do not have to take part if you do not want to. 



3. What will my involvement be?

This survey takes about 5 minutes. You will need to read instructions and answer some multiple choice and rank-order questions. There are 3 open-ended questions where you have to briefly write/explain an answer. 



4. How do I withdraw from the study?

You can withdraw from the study at any point until you have completed the survey, without having to give a reason. If any questions make you feel uncomfortable, you can stop answering. We will not analyze any incomplete responses, so if you stop the survey before the end, your responses will not be included in any analyses or reports.  



5. What will my information be used for?

I will use the survey responses for an academic paper. I may also share my findings in research talks, reports, blog posts, etc. 



6. Will my taking part and my data be kept confidential? Will it be anonymised?

Your data will be anonymised – you do not give your name so your responses can not be matched back to you. The data will be posted on a website where other researchers can analyze it to check my results or test their own hypotheses. Before it is posted, Prolific IDs and IP addresses will be deleted. 



8. Who has reviewed this study?

This study has undergone ethics review in accordance with the LSE Research Ethics Policy and Procedure.



9. Data Protection Privacy Notice

The LSE Research Privacy Policy can be found at: https://info.lse.ac.uk/staff/divisions/Secretarys-Division/Assets/Documents/Information-Records-Management/Privacy-Notice-for-Research-v1.1.pdf



The legal basis used to process your personal data will be "Public Task." The legal basis used to process special category personal data (e.g. data that reveals racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, health, sex life or sexual orientation, genetic or biometric data) will be for scientific and historical research or statistical purposes.

To request a copy of the data held about you please contact: glpd.info.rights@lse.ac.uk



10. What if I have a question or complaint?

If you have any questions regarding this study please contact the researcher, Dr. Heather Kappes, on h.kappes@lse.ac.uk 

If you have any concerns or complaints regarding the conduct of this research, please contact the LSE Research Governance Manager via research.ethics@lse.ac.uk. 



If you are happy to take part in this study, please tick below.
jw_scale_1: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people get what they are entitled to have.
jw_scale_2: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that a person's efforts are noticed and rewarded.
jw_scale_3: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people earn the rewards and punishments they get.
jw_scale_4: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people who meet with misfortune have brought it on themselves.
jw_scale_5: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people get what they deserve.
jw_scale_6: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that rewards and punishments are fairly given.
jw_scale_7: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I basically feel that the world is a fair place.
w_rankfair_1:
The local government is giving grants to small businesses to help with COVID-19. Here's the process they are using:

 

(1) Small businesses applied asking the government for help

(2) The government checked to see if a small business was eligible

(3) Among the eligible small businesses, the agency is considering using one of the following three methods to select which 500 small businesses will get a grant.

 


Please rank-order these three methods, with the best at the top and the worst at the bottom, in terms of how fair they are. Put the method that's the most fair at the top (1) and the method that's the least fair at the bottom (3). - Lottery: The government randomly selects 500 of the businesses to get the money.
w_rankfair_2:
The local government is giving grants to small businesses to help with COVID-19. Here's the process they are using:

 

(1) Small businesses applied asking the government for help

(2) The government checked to see if a small business was eligible

(3) Among the eligible small businesses, the agency is considering using one of the following three methods to select which 500 small businesses will get a grant.

 


Please rank-order these three methods, with the best at the top and the worst at the bottom, in terms of how fair they are. Put the method that's the most fair at the top (1) and the method that's the least fair at the bottom (3). - First-come, first-served: The government gives the money to the first 500 businesses that apply.
w_rankfair_3:
The local government is giving grants to small businesses to help with COVID-19. Here's the process they are using:

 

(1) Small businesses applied asking the government for help

(2) The government checked to see if a small business was eligible

(3) Among the eligible small businesses, the agency is considering using one of the following three methods to select which 500 small businesses will get a grant.

 


Please rank-order these three methods, with the best at the top and the worst at the bottom, in terms of how fair they are. Put the method that's the most fair at the top (1) and the method that's the least fair at the bottom (3). - Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.
pf_fr_1: You think a points system is the most fair way for the government to select which businesses to help. Why do you think a points system is MORE fair than first-come, first-served and a lottery?
pf_fr_2: And you think first-come, first-served is more fair than a lottery. Why do you think a lottery is least fair?
pf_time:
Some of the methods that local governments used were faster at getting money to businesses. Faster was better, because businesses needed the money to pay bills and stay open.
 

Imagine that you learn that the method you think is most fair---a points system---means businesses must wait longer to get money than if the government uses first-come, first-served. How much extra time do you think it's okay to make businesses wait?
pl_fr_1: You think a points system is the most fair way for the government to select which businesses to help. Why do you think a points system is MORE fair than a lottery and first-come, first-served?
pl_fr_2: And you think a lottery is more fair than first-come first-served. Why do you think first-come first-served is least fair?

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
lf_fr_1: I think a lottery is most fair because it is randomly selected. A first-come, first-served and points based system have inherent biases to them. Specifically, the points system will prioritize businesses over others on account of characteristics like race, which I feel is unfair, even if the purpose is to help. Furthermore, if all the businesses are eligible in the first place, I feel as though a points based system to track damages and etc are redundant. The first-come, first-served business model is less random than a lottery, because it benefits those who have the privilege of knowing about the services first.
lf_fr_2: Points system categorizes businesses on account of characteristics such as race that will be inherently biased. Not all minority owned businesses need help, and not all white owned businesses don't need help, so it seems discriminatory to give money to people based on a preconceived notion rather than what they actually need.
lf_time: Only use a lottery if it gets money to businesses as quickly as first-come first-served
m_outcomes: I think it completely depends on the area in which the lottery is conducted. Some areas have a higher percentage of minority owned businesses, so they would be the ones more likely to benefit by chance. Conversely, if it's an area with mostly white owned businesses, then they would be the most likely to benefit. I think it is impossible to say which would do better, just that it would be random and done fairly.
first_choice: Lottery: The government randomly selects 500 of the businesses to get the money.

lp_fr_1: It is the most fair by virtue of its complete lack of distinction. No matter the characteristics of a business or business owner, each has an equal chance of being chosen.
lp_fr_2: I think that first-come first-served is less fair than a lottery, because it still places a preferential treatment upon those who come first, rather than having no preference at all. consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pf_fr_1:
The points system is more effective than first come, first served because it makes it makes it so that people who are in need of a grant more of a priority than the rest of the people applying. If the business owners are able to keep their businesses it keeps them employed  
which in turn stabilizes the economy & keeps America progressive.
pf_fr_2:
I feel like people who are actively looking into
getting a grant to save their business should be more likely to receive the money available first rather than doing a lottery because by giving it to people randomly is not as fair as it would be if the grants were distributed to the people who are taking the initiative to do whatever they can to help themselves better their situation. I have been in many lotteries for housing & for years I was entered into so many different lotteties but could never obtain housing because due to the lotteties I would rank all different numbers in the pool. One time I finally ranked number 12 in a lottery that had 13 apartments available so I felt like I was definitely going to be moving into one of these apartments only to find myself stuck on the same waiting list for the next year & a half. Needless to say, I was very frustrated because I would constantly be putting in the time, effort, & dedication to fill out hundreds of applications only to be randomly ranked in different places due to the lottery & had it been based off of "first come, first served" I am confident that I would have been much more likely to obtain housing because I was taking the initiative to actively look for housing everyday. If you are dedicated to what you are trying to do I feel that is admirable & should be taken into consideration when dispersing any available grants.
pf_time: Use a points system even if it takes 1 month longer to get money to businesses than first-come first-served
w_outcomes: I think that woman would do quite well with that system, especially because many  businesses that are hurting during this time are woman owned businesses such as nail salons, hair salons, & health & beauty stores & boutiques.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.
